page.title: 01Introduction
page.content: The area lies immediately to the east of the urban-industrial complex of Port Talbot and comprises part of the upland plateau of the South Wales coalfield. Poor soils and rough grass -land favoured upland farming, but today much of the area is covered by conifer plantations owned by the Forestry Commission. Sheep graze the remaining grassland. Mynydd Margam is probably the site of the greatest number of prehistoric relics in the County of West Glamorgan. In the south, Margam Country Park a major tourist attraction, lies astride the southern escarpment of the coal- field and is separated from the sea by a narrow coastal plain which is the main routeway for road and rail comm- unications in South Wales. Extensive drilling and seismic surveys continue for the proposed Margam drift mine.
